instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fanspin, no post
threads.message:
All voltages present, clock chip replaced, no light on USB mouse. Even tried different BIOS, but nothing changed. No liquid damage, it just stopped working.
Dead CPU the only possibility?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fanspin, no post
threads.message:
All voltages present ont he MLB, even VCORE?
Pin 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> steady high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fanspin, no post
threads.message: Yes, all of them are present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fanspin, no post
threads.message:
None of USB ports works?
Try MLB without LIO flex connected; no trackpad, nor other perypheral.
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> goes high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fanspin, no post
threads.message:
Nope, non of the USB ports work. This was tested without anything connected.
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fanspin, no post
threads.message:
Check if <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_BUF_L</SIGNAL> is high too.
Also check if you get correct voltage on all the L/C blocks near CPU (PCH corner).
